DOC.HEAD: Keating Brother Dismissed As Defendant In $1.1 Billion Lawsuit
DOC.TEXT: Federal lawyers have dismissed William J. Keating as a defendant in a $1.1 billion lawsuit stemming from the failure of a savings and loan run by his brother, millionaire Charles H. Keating Jr. The lawsuit accused Charles Keating, several family members, and other senior executives of his American Continental Corp. of devising a scheme to loot money from Lincoln Savings and Loan Association of Irving, Calif., which American Continental owned. Federal regulators seized the thrift April 14, one day after American Continental sought protection from its creditors under federal bankruptcy law. The thrift's failure is expected to cost taxpayers more than $2 billion. The Resolution Trust Corp., the federal agency created to clean up the savings and loan industry, filed the lawsuit under civil fraud and racketeering statutes in U.S. District Court in September. William Keating, chief executive officer of the Detroit Newspaper Agency and chairman of the board of The Associated Press, wasn't accused of fraud and racketeering but was named in three of 15 counts and was accused of negligence and breach of fiduciary duty. William Keating served for five months in 1986 on American Continental's board of directors, said his lawyer, Chester T. Kamin of Chicago. Resolution Trust Corp. lawyers filed notice Friday in federal court that William Keating had been dismissed, without prejudice, as a defendant in the case. Kamin said that because the dismissal is ``without prejudice,'' William Keating theoretically could be reinstated as a defendant in the case. But it is unlikely that he would have been dismissed if the government had any intention of including him in the litigation, Kamin said. Michael C. Manning, a Phoenix lawyer who has represented the Resolution Trust Corporation in the case, wasn't available for comment Friday. His secretary said he was on vacation. P. John Owen, a Kansas City lawyer who signed the notice of dismissal on behalf of the Resolution Trust Corporation, was out of his office and unavailable until Tuesday, his secretary said.
